p: The Lavandula genus is an important member of family Lamiaceae. It consists of 47 species of small evergreen shrubs having aromatic foliage and flowers [ 1]. Lavandula species are cultivated in France, Spain, and Italy. In Turkey, mainly two species, Lavandula stoechas and Lavandula angustifolia, and their subspecies and hybrid forms grow wildly or are cultivated [ 2]. The medicinal importance of the plant is well documented [ 3, 4], and the drugs prepared from this plant are registered in many Pharmacopeia [ 5]. L. stoechas L. is used in perfumery and cosmetics [ 6, 7]. Anticonvulsant, sedative, and antispasmodic activities were reported [ 8]. The essential oil (EO) of L. stoechas possesses weak antibacterial activity [ 9]. It is used in folk medicine as an antispasmodic, a sedative, and a diuretic and for rheumatic diseases [ 7]. The main purpose of this study was to investigate the antimicrobial activity of L. stoechas and reveal the major components of its ethanol extracts.
